title: Workshop on VR-Based Scientific Inquiry Learning Environment Design and Facilitation Strategies: Integrated Approach to Experiments, Hypotheses, and Variable Control

context.prior_knowledge: Basic VR technology understanding, intermediate science expertise (experimental design, variable control, data analysis, scientific evidence interpretation), and foundational grasp of the scientific inquiry process (observation, hypothesis formulation, experimentation, conclusion)
context.additional_context: Strengthening competencies in creating and applying VR-based science education content—focusing on integrating the scientific inquiry process (observation, hypothesis formation, experimentation, conclusion-drawing) into VR environments. Learners experience variable control in virtual labs, analyze measurement data, and derive conclusions based on scientific evidence.

learning_goals: Learners can enhance knowledge acquisition of scientific concepts (e.g., chemical reaction mechanisms, physics laws) by over 20% by combining VR animations and auditory texts in an optimized sequence.

Learners can derive work process improvements using three in-depth questioning strategies (e.g., "Why is this step necessary?", "Are there alternative methods?", "What problems might occur during actual work?") in VR-based industrial simulations and achieve an "excellent" rating in at least four out of five rubric categories (clarity, practicality, creativity, scientific validity, experimental design suitability), with a focus on variable control and evidence-based conclusions.

Learners can propose at least three VR-text integration strategies according to sequence design principles and scientific inquiry procedures (observation → hypothesis setting → experiment design → data analysis → conclusion).
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
